question: Do high-citation lessons decay in accuracy over time as the swarm's beliefs evolve?
method: Citation graph analysis of top-20 most-cited lessons + manual staleness audit against current beliefs/principles

staleness_criteria: mechanism_superseded: specific tool/metric/protocol replaced by successor
framing_contradicted: theoretical framing directly falsified by subsequent evidence
valid_canonical: still accurate, absorbed into higher-level conclusions
valid_active: still accurate and actively cited

top_20_lessons.note: composite 'works' but cycles alone are better (L-044/L-055); B9 still observed but B10 supersedes it for prediction
automation principle valid; composite metric superseded by cycle-first approach (L-044/L-055)
edge-of-chaos framing directly contradicted by F9-NK RESOLVED (S357, L-613/L-618): K=2.0 smooth crossing, all 4 chaos predictions FALSIFIED. Core principle (interconnect beliefs) still valid.
HANDOFF.md never adopted; NEXT.md session notes + orient.py replaced it. Core principle (commit = checkpoint) still valid.
principle repeatedly confirmed (L-599 hallucination audit). Numbers are era-specific.

freshness_gap_distribution.note: bimodal: either <10 sessions old or >100 sessions old

analysis.freshness_vs_staleness: All 4 stale/tension lessons are genesis-era (S0). But 7/20 are also S0 and VALID — age alone does not predict staleness. Stale lessons share: specific metric/tool recommendations that were tested and superseded.
analysis.decay_mechanism: Knowledge decays at the mechanism layer (which tool, which metric, which protocol) not the principle layer (why, what pattern). L-025 'edge of chaos' is the only framing-level contradiction — and it required 357 sessions of measurement to falsify.
analysis.citation_count_protective: Partially. High-citation lessons get MORE subsequent testing (L-022 → L-599 hallucination audit) which PREVENTS principle decay. But mechanism-level claims in high-citation lessons propagate longer before correction.
analysis.staleness_signal: Best predictor is not freshness_gap but 'does the lesson recommend a specific tool/metric/protocol that was subsequently tested?' If yes and the test found a better alternative, the lesson is stale.

hypothesis_test.hypothesis: ~5% of high-citation lessons are stale by current belief state
hypothesis_test.verdict: CONFIRMED at strict threshold, EXCEEDED at broad threshold
hypothesis_test.note: The 5% hypothesis was well-calibrated for hard contradictions. But mechanism-level staleness (tools/metrics superseded) is 4x more common than principle contradictions.
